turns.speaker: learner

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Of course! So I was just asking if you already have a specific master's program in mind here in Sydney, or if you need a bit of help choosing the right one for your goals.

turns.speaker: learner

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Got it! So you're interested in something related to policy. Now let me ask: are you more interested in public policy, like government and social issues, or maybe something like economic policy?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Economic policies, because I already had an economic master's degree in Korea.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Sure, that lines up perfectly. So you're leaning toward something in economic policy. Now, let's figure out the next step: have you already looked at which universities in Sydney offer that kind of program, or do you need a bit of help with that part?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “I don't know the Sydney programs well, so can you tell me the difference? And what is the diploma before master's degree?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely, I can help with that. So, basically in Sydney, some universities offer a graduate diploma that you can do before a full master's. It's like a stepping stone. Now, let me ask you: would you prefer to start with that kind of diploma program to get familiar with the field, or do you want to jump straight into a master's program if possible?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “I got it.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Great! So now that you’ve got that, let me know: would you rather ease in with a diploma first, or just go straight into the master’s if you can?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “How long I take a diploma?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Sure! So typically a graduate diploma might take around a year of full-time study. Now, does that timeline sound like something that would fit into your plans, or are you hoping for something shorter?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Should I do a default LOMA before a master's degree?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Sure! So generally, doing a diploma first can help if you want a smoother entry into a master's, especially if you want to build up some local credentials. So my question for you is: do you feel like you'd be more comfortable easing in that way, or are you confident you want to jump straight into the master's program directly?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “I'm not good at English school. Is it okay?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely, that's totally okay. We can work with that. In fact, starting with a diploma might actually give you some extra time to get comfortable with English. So would you like to go that route and get a bit more used to studying in English first, or do you have another idea in mind?

turns.speaker: learner

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Great! That sounds like

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Sure, that makes total sense. Sometimes it just takes a little chatting to see the options. So let me ask: do you feel ready to look into some specific diploma programs now, or do you want to talk through anything else first?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Okay, thanks for your time.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Of course! Happy to help. And if you need anything else, just let me know. Otherwise, take care and good luck with everything!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Okay, thank you.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: You're welcome! Take care and all the best with your studies. If you need any more advice, just drop by anytime.

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Can I ask one more?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely! Go right ahead and ask whatever you need.

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Sure! So funding

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “or Muni, who've taken a similar path.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely, plenty of students take a similar path, so you're definitely not alone in that. Now, just to help you further: are you interested in connecting with any student groups or resources that can guide you along the way?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Okay, thank you.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: You're very welcome! And if you need anything else down the line, just let me know. Otherwise, take care and good luck!

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Bye-bye.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Bye! Take care and have a great day. Task 2: Participateing in Group Decisions

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: All right, bye-bye! Have a good one, and we'll talk soon 3) Responding to Feedback

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Hello.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Hello there! What can I do for you today?

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely! Go ahead

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “And I'm participating in feedback section with teacher, manager, or supervisor, whatever you want. You need to listen activity, and ask a question, respond respectful, like this.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Alright, I can do that! So, let’s say I’m your manager here for a feedback session. To get us started, what’s one thing you’d like to discuss or get feedback on today?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Yes.”

turns.text: Great! So let

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Hi again! So let's jump in. What's one area where you'd like some feedback or have a question about how you're doing?

turns.text: “We have just finished our group project. Could you please share your comments?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Sure! I'd be happy to share my thoughts. Overall, you did a really solid job on that group project. Now, can you tell me which part of the project you personally found most challenging?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Oh sorry, can you save it again?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Of course! So, just to share my comments again: you did a really solid job on the project overall. And I'm curious, what part of it did you find the most challenging personally?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Challenging most confidence?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Got it! So the most challenging part for you was building up your confidence. That makes sense and it's totally normal. Now, is there a specific situation where you felt that confidence was the hardest for you?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Okay, thanks. I will make sure to check detail more carefully.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Absolutely! That sounds like a good plan. And is there anything else you'd like some feedback on or any other area you'd like to discuss?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Do you mean I should change?”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Sure, I get what you're asking. I just mean maybe it's about small improvements, not necessarily changing who you are. So is there a particular skill you feel you'd like to improve on going forward?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “I will make those changes and update later.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Alright, that sounds like a good approach. So we can definitely touch base after you've made those updates. Anything else on your mind that you'd like to go over right now?

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Yes, is this finish it your comment?”

turns.speaker: bot

turns.speaker: learner

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: Sure thing! I'm glad it was helpful. If you have any more questions later, just let me know.

turns.speaker: learner
turns.text: “Yeah, that's all. Thank you.”

turns.speaker: bot
turns.text: You’re welcome! Glad I could help. Take care and see you next time!
